question: Who is Joan FitzGerald, Countess of Carrick married to?

content.source_1: In the lush emerald hills of medieval Ireland, a tale of power, loyalty, and matrimony unfolded, binding two noble families together in a union that would shape the course of history. At the heart of this narrative lies the assertion that Joan FitzGerald, Countess of Carrick, was married to Edmund Butler, Earl of Carrick. As we delve into the intricacies of their lives, the evidence will reveal a complex web of alliances, family ties, and strategic maneuvering that underscores the validity of this claim. In the early 14th century, the FitzGerald family, one of the most influential Anglo-Norman dynasties in Ireland, held significant sway over the kingdom. Joan, a member of this esteemed clan, was born into a world of privilege and expectation. Her family's power was rooted in their control of the earldom of Kildare, a strategic stronghold that commanded the fertile plains of Leinster. As a woman of noble birth, Joan's marriage was a crucial tool in securing alliances and expanding her family's influence. Meanwhile, Edmund Butler, a scion of the Butler family, had risen to prominence as a skilled military leader and justiciar of Ireland. The Butlers, another prominent Anglo-Norman family, had established themselves in Ireland during the 12th century and had since become entrenched in the country's power structure. Edmund's appointment as justiciar, a position akin to chief governor, demonstrated his family's growing influence and his own reputation as a capable administrator. The marriage between Joan and Edmund was a masterstroke of strategic diplomacy. By uniting the FitzGerald and Butler families, the couple's union created a powerful bloc that spanned the length and breadth of Ireland. This alliance not only strengthened their respective families' positions but also provided a bulwark against the encroaching influence of the English monarchy. One of the earliest recorded references to their marriage appears in the Calendar of Justiciary Rolls of Ireland, which dates back to 1326. This document, a treasure trove of historical information, reveals that Edmund Butler, as justiciar, was involved in a land dispute with the bishop of Ferns. Significantly, the record notes that Edmund's wife, Joan, was present at the proceedings, underscoring her role as a key player in her husband's administrative duties. Further evidence of their marriage can be found in the annals of the Irish chancery, which detail the issuance of royal charters and grants.
